title: Frontend Developer
description: Build beautiful, responsive user interfaces that users love

foundation.title: Foundation Phase
foundation.subtitle: Master the 'Why' Before the 'How'
foundation.description: Before writing a single line of code, understand the principles that make great frontend developers.

modules.title: Design Principles
modules.description: Learn visual hierarchy, spacing, color theory, and typography fundamentals

topics.title: Visual Hierarchy
topics.what: The arrangement of elements that shows their importance
topics.why: Users scan, not read. Hierarchy guides their eyes to what matters.
topics.industry_example: Google's homepage: one input, one button. Everything else fades away.
common_mistakes: Too many bold elements competing for attention
topics.senior_tip: Squint at your design. What stands out? That's your hierarchy.

topics.title: Spacing & Rhythm
topics.what: Consistent use of whitespace between elements
topics.why: Cramped designs feel cheap. Breathing room feels premium.
topics.industry_example: Apple's product pages use massive whitespace to feel luxurious.
topics.senior_tip: Use a spacing scale (4, 8, 16, 24, 32, 48px). Never invent random values.

topics.title: Color Theory Basics
topics.what: How colors work together and affect perception
topics.why: Wrong colors = unprofessional. Right colors = trust and emotion.
topics.industry_example: Banks use blue (trust). Food apps use red/orange (appetite).
common_mistakes: Using pure black (#000) on pure white
topics.senior_tip: Pick 1 primary, 1 accent, and 2-3 neutrals. That's it.

modules.title: Layout Reasoning
modules.description: Understand when to use Flexbox vs Grid, and why certain layouts work

topics.title: Flexbox vs Grid: The Decision
topics.what: Two CSS layout systems with different strengths
topics.why: Using the wrong one makes code messy. Using the right one feels effortless.
common_mistakes: Using Grid for simple centering (Flexbox is simpler)
Fighting the default behavior instead of using the right tool

topics.title: Responsive Design Thinking
topics.what: Designing for all screen sizes, not just desktop
topics.why: 60%+ of web traffic is mobile. Desktop-only designs fail.

approach.mobile_first: Start with mobile, add complexity for larger screens
approach.why_mobile_first: It's easier to add than remove. Mobile forces you to prioritize.

common_mistakes: Designing desktop first, then squishing for mobile
Fixed pixel widths instead of percentages/fr units
Breakpoints that don't match real content needs
topics.senior_tip: Resize your browser constantly while developing. Never assume one size.

modules.title: UX Thinking
modules.description: Think about users, not pixels. How real people interact with interfaces.

topics.title: User Flow Basics
topics.what: The path a user takes to complete a task
topics.why: Confusing flows = abandoned carts, lost users, failed products.
topics.industry_example: Amazon's 1-click buy: reduced friction = billions in revenue.
common_mistakes: Too many steps to complete simple actions
topics.senior_tip: Every click is a chance to lose the user. Minimize clicks ruthlessly.

topics.title: Accessibility Basics
topics.what: Making interfaces usable by everyone, including people with disabilities
topics.why: 1B+ people have disabilities. It's also the law in many countries.
common_mistakes: Relying only on color to convey meaning
topics.senior_tip: Use your site with keyboard only. If you can't, fix it.

outcomes: Think in components and design systems
Debug CSS issues like a senior developer
